contents.title: Steff Beckers
contents.description: I'm a passionate developer with a strong focus on web development and DevOps. I thrive on learning and working with the latest technologies and frameworks to continuously grow my expertise. I enjoy collaborating as part of a team in an agile environment, where I can contribute to building impactful solutions. I'm detail-oriented, committed to getting things right, and understand that even the smallest details can make a big difference.

contents.title: Chocolatey, the package manager for Windows
contents.description: Chocolatey has the largest online registry of Windows packages. Chocolatey packages encapsulate everything required to manage a particular piece of software into one deployment artifact by wrapping installers, executables, zips, and/or scripts into a compiled package file.

meta.name: keywords
meta.content: Chocolatey, DEV, Commands, PowerShell, Windows, Packages, Installers, Steff, Beckers, Blog

contents.title: IIS Express 10 localhost SSL certificate reset
contents.description: Tutorial on how to reset your localhost SSL certificate for IIS Express 10.

meta.name: keywords
meta.content: Tutorial, how to, reset, IIS, Express, HTTPS, SSL, Certificate, .NET, API, Visual Studio, VS, Steff, Beckers, Blog

children.value: Quick test .NET Web API project to test the problem, fix the issue and check if it's working again.
While running a test .NET Web API using IIS Express, the
:... site can't be reached or some other error like "invalid SSL certificate".

props.alt: Visual studio running a Web API with IIS Express screenshot
This site can't be reached screenshot

children.value: But if we run the API with Kestrel, the site just works fine.

props.alt: Visual studio running a Web API with Kestrel screenshot
Test Web API swagger UI screenshot

children.value: Or maybe this isn't even working for you.
Open the Windows Certificate Manager by searching for "certificate". Choose "Manage user certificates".
Select all localhost certificates in the "Personal/Certificates" folder and delete them.
Select all localhost certificates in the "Trusted Root Certification Authorities/Certificates" folder and delete them.

props.alt: Certificate manager user trusted root screenshot

children.value: Now do the same thing but for your local computer certificates.

props.alt: Certificate manager computer trusted root screenshot

children.value: Step 2: Use the IIS Express admin CLI
Open a new powershell or cmd prompt as Administrator (elevated permissions).
Change directory to your IIS Express installation folder.
Now execute the following command to re-run the setup for the SSL certificates.

props.alt: Windows Terminal reset IIS Express SSL screenshot

children.value: Make sure to restart Visual Studio, this will also stop IIS Express.
Step 4: Re-run your application with IIS Express
Select IIS Express in your debug/run configuration and start the application.
Now you should get a pop-up to trust the new self-signed SSL certificate for your localhost app, we generated/setup in step 2. Choose "Yes" to trust the certificate.

props.alt: Visual studio running a Web API with IIS Express SSL pop-up screenshot

children.value: This pop-up should follow. This is a security warning you get before installing new certificates on your local machine. Choose "Yes" to install the certificate.

props.alt: Visual studio running a Web API with IIS Express SSL pop-up warning screenshot

children.value: After installing the certificate the app should start correctly and the SSL problem should be fixed.
Now we get the "Application started. ..." ouput, in the Output window within Visual Studio.

props.alt: Visual studio running a Web API with IIS Express with output screenshot

children.value: Navigate/browse to the web page to test if the SSL certificate is fixed.

props.alt: Test Web API swagger UI screenshot

children.value: Also check out this GitHub Gist:

This powershell script generates a new certificate, removes the old certificate assignments from the IISExpress ssl ports and adds the newly generated one. The certificate is also copied over to the Trusted Root Certificate Authorities.
This can help to reset all SSL certificates within the IIS Express port range 44300-44399. Make sure to open a powershell prompt as Administrator (elevated permissions).

children.text: Step 2: Use the IIS Express admin CLI
Step 4: Re-run your application with IIS Express
